translated: Birth Stories
The Four-Collection🔽The Chapter with Kuṭidūsaka
The Birth Story of Kāḷabāhu
“What we used to get for food and drink,
now goes to the deer in the forest;
Now we will go to the forest, Rādha,
we are not respected by Dhanañjaya.”
“Gain and loss, fame and lack of fame,
blame and praise, pleasure and pain;
these are impermanent things among humans,
don’t grieve, why do you grieve, Poṭṭhapāda?”
“Surely you are wise, Rādha,
you know the future;
how will we see the deer in the forest,
who has escaped from the royal house?”
“He flicks his ears, he makes a frown,
he is constantly threatening the prince;
he will make himself Kāḷabāhu,

analyzed: yena arakā ṭhassati anna pānā ti
translated: by which he will stand in food and drink.”
The Birth Story of Kāḷabāhu, ninth.
